In his otherwise commendable ''Suburban Life'' editorial (''The 185 Tequilas of Alida Yougez,'' Jan. 8), Lawrence Downes unfortunately perpetuates a common misunderstanding, by using the words ''Anglo'' and ''Caucasian'' interchangeably to describe the non-Hispanic population of Westchester.

''Hispanic'' and ''Latino'' are broad cultural designations that encompass people with a wide variety of ancestries (European, African, Native American and so on). ''Caucasian'' is a specifically ''racial'' classification -- one that, according to the American Heritage Dictionary, is ''no longer in scientific use.'' As the United States Census Bureau makes clear, ''race and Hispanic origin are considered two separate concepts and therefore Hispanics may be of any race or races.''
